head.title: Padé Interpolation: Methodology and Application to Quarkonium

article.h1:
Padé Interpolation:
Methodology and Application to Quarkonium

span.span: C. N. Leung and J. A. Murakowski111Present address: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Delaware, Newark, DE 19716, U.S.A.

Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Delaware
Newark, DE 19716, U.S.A.

div.p: A novel application of the Padé approximation is proposed in which the Padé approximant is used as an interpolation for the small and large coupling behaviors of a physical system, resulting in a prediction of the behavior of the system at intermediate couplings. This method is applied to quarkonium systems and reasonable values for the c𝑐italic-cc and b𝑏italic-bb quark masses are obtained.

The Padé approximation seeks to approximate the behavior of a function, f⁢(x)𝑓𝑥italic-f OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)f(x), by a ratio of two polynomials of x𝑥italic-xx. This ratio is referred to as the Padé approximant. Compared to the usual perturbative power series approximation, the Padé approximant has the advantage that it deviates less rapidly from the true values of f⁢(x)𝑓𝑥italic-f OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)f(x) as x𝑥italic-xx becomes large. Recently, the Padé approximation has been applied to quantum field theories to estimate the next order term in a perturbation series[1]. The method involves calculating a certain physical quantity perturbatively to n𝑛italic-nnth order in the coupling constant and then forming a Padé approximant which, when expanded in a power series of the coupling constant, reproduces the perturbative result. The (n+1)𝑛1OPEN:( italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:)(n+1)th order term in the expansion of the Padé approximant yields an estimate of the (n+1)𝑛1OPEN:( italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:)(n+1)th order term in the perturbation series for the physical quantity. It turns out one can obtain reasonably good estimates from this approach.

In this paper a different usage of the Padé approximation is proposed. We observe that, because of the nature of the Padé approximant, it can be expanded in a power series in x𝑥italic-xx when x𝑥italic-xx is small as well as in a power series in 1x1𝑥FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-x ARG:end\frac{1}{x} when x𝑥italic-xx is large. It is therefore interesting to ask the question: in cases when both the small x𝑥italic-xx (e.g., weak coupling) and the large x𝑥italic-xx (e.g., strong coupling) behaviors of a theory can be computed perturbatively, is it possible to form a single Padé approximant which interpolates the weak and strong coupling behaviors, and if so, how well does this Padé interpolation approximate the behaviors of the theory at intermediate values of the coupling constant? This is a particularly timely question since, with the advance of duality in supersymmetric gauge theories[2], we may someday be able to compute the strong coupling behaviors of a theory from its dual theory. The Padé interpolation will then provide a means to estimate the behaviors of the theory for the entire range of the coupling constant.

The method proposed here goes beyond interpolating the strong and weak coupling behaviors of a system. For example, the expansion parameter x𝑥italic-xx can be the temperature, the strength of an applied field, or, as discussed below in the application to heavy quarkonia, a parameter introduced to implement the Padé interpolation.

We have tested the Padé interpolation method with examples in which the exact result is known, with encouraging success. To see how accurate the Padé interpolation can be and to illustrate the methodology involved, let us consider a simple quantum mechanical two-state system with the Hamiltonian,

semantics.annotation: italic-H RELOP:equals italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-lambda italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where the σ𝜎italic-sigma\sigma’s are the Pauli matrices and the coupling constant λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda is assumed to be positive. For λ≪1much-less-than𝜆1italic-lambda RELOP:much-less-than NUMBER:1\lambda\ll 1, the σzsubscript𝜎𝑧italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{z} term may be treated as a perturbation and we find, to second order in perturbation theory, the eigenvalues of H𝐻italic-HH are

semantics.annotation: italic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start RELOP:less-than POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus-or-minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus-or-minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-lambda POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end PERIOD:.

div.p: For λ≫1much-greater-than𝜆1italic-lambda RELOP:much-greater-than NUMBER:1\lambda\gg 1, the Hamiltonian can be written as H=λ⁢(σz+1λ⁢σx)𝐻𝜆subscript𝜎𝑧1𝜆subscript𝜎𝑥italic-H RELOP:equals italic-lambda OPEN:( italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-z POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-lambda ARG:end italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)H=\lambda(\sigma_{z}+\frac{1}{\lambda}\sigma_{x}), and the σxsubscript𝜎𝑥italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{x} term can be treated as a perturbation. We find, again to second order in perturbation theory, the eigenvalues of H𝐻italic-HH are now

semantics.annotation: italic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start RELOP:greater-than POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus-or-minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus-or-minus italic-lambda ADDOP:plus-or-minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-lambda ARG:end PERIOD:.

div.p: A Padé approximant which interpolates the small and large λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda behaviors of the energies can now be constructed. For the higher energy level E+subscript𝐸italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{+}, we find

semantics.annotation: italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( PA CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-lambda POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end italic-lambda POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end italic-lambda ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-lambda POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end italic-lambda ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 ARG:end PERIOD:.

div.p: This Padé approximant is uniquely determined from the perturbative expansions for E+subscript𝐸italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{+} given in (2) and (3). The large λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda behavior indicates that the polynomial in the numerator must be one degree higher than the polynomial in the denominator and that the coefficient for the highest order term in λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda must be the same for the two polynomials. Without loss of generality, we may choose this coefficient to be 1. If the numerator is a polynomial of degree d𝑑italic-dd, there will be a total of (2⁢d-1)2𝑑1OPEN:( NUMBER:2 italic-d ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:)(2d-1) coefficients to be determined for the Padé approximant. Because the small λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda behavior requires the numerator and the denominator to have the same constant (i.e., λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda-independent) term, there are only (2⁢d-2)2𝑑2OPEN:( NUMBER:2 italic-d ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 CLOSE:)(2d-2) remaining coefficients to be determined. Expanding the Padé approximant and matching against the perturbation series in (2) and (3) provide an additional four conditions, which selects d=3𝑑3italic-d RELOP:equals NUMBER:3d=3.

In Figure 1, the approximate result generated from Padé interpolation is compared with the exact result, E+=λ2+1subscript𝐸superscript𝜆21italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-square-root ARG:start italic-lambda POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 ARG:endE_{+}=\sqrt{\lambda^{2}+1}. We see that the Padé approximant (open squares) tracks the exact result (solid curve) for all values of the coupling constant. In fact, E+(PA)superscriptsubscript𝐸PAitalic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( PA CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endE_{+}^{(\rm PA)} differs from E+subscript𝐸italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{+} by no more than about 1% for the entire range of λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda. For example, for λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda = 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, and 4.0, E+(PA)superscriptsubscript𝐸PAitalic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( PA CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endE_{+}^{(\rm PA)} is larger than E+subscript𝐸italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{+} by 0.63%, 1.02%, 0.62%, and 0.18%, respectively. One may improve the approximation by calculating more terms in the perturbation series for E+<subscriptsuperscript𝐸italic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start RELOP:less-than POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE^{<}_{+} and E+>subscriptsuperscript𝐸italic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start RELOP:greater-than POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE^{>}_{+} and constructing the corresponding Padé approximant. However, our example suffices to demonstrate the potential power of the Padé interpolation method in that very few terms in the perturbation expansions can yield a very accurate approximation to the exact result for the entire range of the coupling constant.

For comparison, we have also plotted in Figure 1 the perturbative result for small λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda, E+<subscriptsuperscript𝐸italic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start RELOP:less-than POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE^{<}_{+} (dotted curve). As expected, it only agrees with the exact result for small values of λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda and diverges significantly from the exact result when λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda becomes large. Similarly, E+>subscriptsuperscript𝐸italic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start RELOP:greater-than POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE^{>}_{+} will diverge from the exact result for small λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda. In contrast, by interpolating E+<subscriptsuperscript𝐸italic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start RELOP:less-than POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE^{<}_{+} and E+>subscriptsuperscript𝐸italic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start RELOP:greater-than POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE^{>}_{+}, the Padé approximant is constrained not to deviate too far from the exact result for the full range of the coupling constant. In this way, the Padé interpolation method can yield a very good approximation, provided the quantity we try to approximate is a smooth, continuous function of the coupling constant.

When applying the Padé interpolation, one should beware of potential unphysical singularities coming from the zeroes of the polynomial in the denominator of the Padé approximant. This complication may limit the scope of applicability of the method. On the other hand, this property may prove useful in some applications. For instance, when interpolating the high and low temperature behaviors of a system for which a phase transition takes place at some intermediate temperature, one may try to construct a Padé-like approximant (perhaps involving fractional powers in the polynomials) which mimics the singular behavior near the phase transition point.

Another way to implement the Padé interpolation method is in cases when the Hamiltonian can be expressed as H=H1+H2𝐻subscript𝐻1subscript𝐻2italic-H RELOP:equals italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH=H_{1}+H_{2}, where the exact solutions for H1subscript𝐻1italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{1} and H2subscript𝐻2italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{2} (but not H𝐻italic-HH) are known. Introducing the interpolating Hamiltonian,

semantics.annotation: italic-H OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:) RELOP:equivalent-to italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-beta italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where β𝛽italic-beta\beta is a positive constant, we can then treat H2subscript𝐻2italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{2} as a perturbation when β≪1much-less-than𝛽1italic-beta RELOP:much-less-than NUMBER:1\beta\ll 1 and treat H1subscript𝐻1italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{1} as a perturbation when β≫1much-greater-than𝛽1italic-beta RELOP:much-greater-than NUMBER:1\beta\gg 1, in exactly the same way as in the example (1). A Padé approximant is formed interpolating the perturbative results for large and small β𝛽italic-beta\beta. Finally, an approximate solution for the original Hamiltonian H𝐻italic-HH is obtained by setting β𝛽italic-beta\beta equal 1 in the Padé approximant. This method will be applied below to calculate quarkonium spectra. Reasonable values for the c𝑐italic-cc and b𝑏italic-bb quark masses are obtained by fitting the calculated levels to their measured values, which demonstrates the legitimacy of this Padé interpolation approach.

Quarkonium refers to the bound state of a heavy quark Q𝑄italic-QQ (e.g., c𝑐italic-cc or b𝑏italic-bb quark) with its antiquark Q¯¯𝑄OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-Q ARG:end\bar{Q}. It is well known that such systems can be described reasonably well using nonrelativistic quantum mechanics[3]. Various potential energy functions have been used to model the Q⁢Q¯𝑄¯𝑄italic-Q OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-Q ARG:endQ\bar{Q} interaction. It has been found that the potential description is flavor independent, i.e., the same potential describes equally well the c⁢c¯𝑐¯𝑐italic-c OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-c ARG:endc\bar{c} and the b⁢b¯𝑏¯𝑏italic-b OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-b ARG:endb\bar{b} systems. We consider here a central potential consisting of an attractive Coulomb term and a confining linear potential[4]:

semantics.annotation: italic-V OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-alpha ARG:end ARG:start italic-r ARG:end ADDOP:plus italic-lambda italic-r PUNCT:,

div.p: where α𝛼italic-alpha\alpha and λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda are positive coupling constants. We shall focus on the S states for the purpose of testing the proposed interpolation method. In this case, the Hamiltonian for the radial Schrödinger equation is simply

semantics.annotation: italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-mu ARG:end FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-d POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-d italic-r POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-alpha ARG:end ARG:start italic-r ARG:end ADDOP:plus italic-lambda italic-r PUNCT:,

div.p: where μ𝜇italic-mu\mu is the reduced mass for the heavy quark Q𝑄italic-QQ, μ=mQ/2𝜇subscript𝑚𝑄2italic-mu RELOP:equals italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:2\mu=m_{Q}/2. Note that Hrsubscript𝐻𝑟italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{r} can be expressed as the sum of two exactly solvable Hamiltonians: a Hamiltonian for the Coulomb potential,

semantics.annotation: italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 italic-mu ARG:end FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-d POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-d italic-r POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-alpha ARG:end ARG:start italic-r ARG:end PUNCT:,

div.p: and a Hamiltonian for the linear potential,

semantics.annotation: italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 italic-mu ARG:end FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-d POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-d italic-r POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ADDOP:plus italic-lambda italic-r PERIOD:.

div.p: We have split the kinetic energy term in half so that the “effective mass” that appears in HCsubscript𝐻𝐶italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{C} and in HLsubscript𝐻𝐿italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{L} is 2⁢μ=mQ2𝜇subscript𝑚𝑄NUMBER:2 italic-mu RELOP:equals italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end2\mu=m_{Q}.

We may now form the interpolating Hamiltonian, Hr⁢(β)=HC+β⁢HLsubscript𝐻𝑟𝛽subscript𝐻𝐶𝛽subscript𝐻𝐿italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-beta italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{r}(\beta)=H_{C}+\beta H_{L}, and perform perturbative calculations for small β𝛽italic-beta\beta as well as for large β𝛽italic-beta\beta. We shall summarize the results of our calculation here. Details of the calculation can be found in Ref.[5] where the calculation including the quarkonium P states is also discussed. (For the P states, the centrifugal pontential energy term, l⁢(l+1)2⁢μ⁢r2𝑙𝑙12𝜇superscript𝑟2FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-l OPEN:( italic-l ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-mu italic-r POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end\frac{l(l+1)}{2\mu r^{2}}, should be included with HCsubscript𝐻𝐶italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{C}, resulting in a solvable ”hydrogen-like” Hamiltonian. Because of the half kinetic energy term, care must be taken to redefine the orbital angular momentum quantum number in order to extract the energy eigenvalues.)

The bound state energies for the S states of Hr⁢(β)subscript𝐻𝑟𝛽italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)H_{r}(\beta) are computed for small β𝛽italic-beta\beta as well as for large β𝛽italic-beta\beta to the same order in perturbation theory. Wherever necessary (e.g., integrals involving the Airy functions, the eigenfunctions of HLsubscript𝐻𝐿italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:endH_{L}), terms in the perturbation series are evaluated numerically. In addition, for second and higher order calculations, the infinite series that appear in the perturbation expansions are estimated using the method of acceleration of convergence[6, 5]. A separate Padé approximant is formed interpolating the small and large β𝛽italic-beta\beta results from our first, second, and third order calculations. Our estimates for the S state energies are obtained by letting β𝛽italic-beta\beta equal 1 in the respective Padé approximant. These are fitted to the corresponding measured values treating α𝛼italic-alpha\alpha, λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda, mcsubscript𝑚𝑐italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{c}, mbsubscript𝑚𝑏italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{b} as well as the zero-point energies Vcsubscript𝑉𝑐italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endV_{c} (for charmonium) and Vbsubscript𝑉𝑏italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:endV_{b} (for bottomonium) as free parameters. We used the data for the J/ψ𝐽𝜓italic-J MULOP:divide italic-psiJ/\psi(1S), J/ψ𝐽𝜓italic-J MULOP:divide italic-psiJ/\psi(2S), ΥΥUpsilon\Upsilon(1S), ΥΥUpsilon\Upsilon(2S), and ΥΥUpsilon\Upsilon(3S) given in Ref.[7]. When performing the fit, care must be taken to avoid the artificial singularities of the Padé approximant.

The details of the fit results are presented in Table 1. We see that the first-order approximation already produces a rather good fit to the measured S-state energies, although the best fit values for mcsubscript𝑚𝑐italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{c} and mbsubscript𝑚𝑏italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{b} are somewhat high. The second-order approximation improves the fit quality, reproducing all of the quarkonium S-levels. The fit quality, defined as ∑i(mi(experiment)-mi(calculated))2subscript𝑖superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑚𝑖(experiment)superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑖(calculated)2SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:(experiment) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ATOM:(calculated) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sum_{i}\left(m_{i}^{\hbox{(experiment)}}-m_{i}^{\hbox{(calculated)}}\right)^{2}, worsens (from less than 1 to 240) as we go to the third-order approximation, primarily due to the increased difficulty to avoid a larger number of unphysical singularities from the Padé approximant in performing the fit. Using the second-order results, our best fit values for mcsubscript𝑚𝑐italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{c} and mbsubscript𝑚𝑏italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{b} are 1.521 GeV and 5.046 GeV, respectively, to be compared with the values given in Ref.[7]: mc=1.0⁢to⁢1.6subscript𝑚𝑐1.0to1.6italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.0 to NUMBER:1.6m_{c}=1.0~{}{\rm to}~{}1.6 GeV; mb=4.1⁢to⁢4.5subscript𝑚𝑏4.1to4.5italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:4.1 to NUMBER:4.5m_{b}=4.1~{}{\rm to}~{}4.5 GeV. The best fit values for the parameters in the quarkonium potential (6), α=0.4984𝛼0.4984italic-alpha RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.4984\alpha=0.4984 and λ=0.1771⁢GeV2𝜆0.1771superscriptGeV2italic-lambda RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1771 GeV POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\lambda=0.1771~{}{\rm GeV}^{2}, also compare favorably with earlier results: α=0.520𝛼0.520italic-alpha RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.520\alpha=0.520 and λ=0.183⁢GeV2𝜆0.183superscriptGeV2italic-lambda RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.183 GeV POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\lambda=0.183~{}{\rm GeV}^{2} in Ref.[8]; α=0.507𝛼0.507italic-alpha RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.507\alpha=0.507 and λ=0.169⁢GeV2𝜆0.169superscriptGeV2italic-lambda RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.169 GeV POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\lambda=0.169~{}{\rm GeV}^{2} in Ref.[3].

We have also performed a fit with the constraint Vb-Vc=2⁢(mb-mc)subscript𝑉𝑏subscript𝑉𝑐2subscript𝑚𝑏subscript𝑚𝑐italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 OPEN:( italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)V_{b}-V_{c}=2(m_{b}-m_{c}) on the model parameters. The results are presented in Table 2. The fit quality in this case is comparable to that of the unconstrained fit and the best fit values of the model parameters differ somewhat from the best fit values of the unconstrained fit, indicating that the found minimum is not sharp and allows for some variation of the quark masses as long as their difference remains equal to half of the difference between the zero-point energies Vbsubscript𝑉𝑏italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:endV_{b} and Vcsubscript𝑉𝑐italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endV_{c}. The model parameters appear to be more stable than before as we go from first to second-order Padé interpolation, which corroborates the physical significance of the constraint.

As a final check, we have integrated numerically the Schrödinger equation for the quarkonium systems with the second-order best fit values of the parameters to obtain the energy levels. The results are shown in the last column of Table 1. This verifies the validity of the Padé interpolation method.

In conclusion, using quarkonia and a simple two-state model as our testing grounds, we have shown that Padé interpolation can be a powerful method for estimating physical quantities at intermediate values of the coupling constant where perturbative calculations are not reliable. There are many areas for which this method may be applicable. One of which is the K-meson system. The strange quark mass, mssubscript𝑚𝑠italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{s}, has the value such that neither chiral perturbation theory (for small quark masses) nor heavy quark effective theory (for large quark masses) gives a good description of K-meson properties. With Padé interpolation we may be able to obtain a more accurate estimate of the K-meson properties by interpolating the small mssubscript𝑚𝑠italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{s} and large mssubscript𝑚𝑠italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{s} behaviors which can be obtained perturbatively through chiral perturbation theory and heavy quark effective theory, respectively. These issues are being examined by one of us and the results will be reported in the near future[9].
This work was supported in part by the U.S. Department of Energy under grant DE-FG02-84ER40163.

li.span: See, e.g., M. A. Samuel, J. Ellis and M. Karliner, Phys. Rev. Lett. 74, 4380 (1995); M. A. Samuel, G. Li and E. Steinfelds, Phys. Rev. E 51, 3911 (1995).
N. Seiberg and E. Witten, Nucl. Phys. B426, 19 (1994); ibid. B431, 484 (1994).
See, e.g., the review by C. Quigg and J. L. Rosner, Phys. Rep. 56, 167 (1979).
E. Eichten, K. Gottfried, T. Kinoshita, J. Kogut, K. D. Lane, and T.-M. Yan, Phys. Rev. Lett. 34, 369 (1975).
J. A. Murakowski, Ph.D. thesis, University of Delaware, 1998 (unpublished).
E. J. Weniger, Computer Physics Reports 10, 189 (1989).
Particle Data Group, R. Barnett et al., Phys. Rev. D 54, 1 (1996).
E. Eichten, K. Gottfried, T. Kinoshita, K. D. Lane, and T.-M. Yan, Phys. Rev. D 21, 203 (1980).
C. N. Leung, ”Padé interpolation II: application to K-mesons”, in preparation.

div.p: Table 1. Fit results from Padé interpolation.
